title: 108_s1385
content: The "Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2003" requires disclosure of fire safety information for campus buildings. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a requirement for eligible institutions to disclose fire safety standards and measures through annual reports starting from the academic year 2004-2005. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment mandates eligible institutions to provide an annual fire safety report to current students, employees, and applicants upon request. The report must include information on campus fire safety practices, statistics on fires and false alarms in student housing facilities, and details on fire safety systems in each housing facility. The annual fire safety report required by the Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment must include details on human injuries, deaths, and structural damage from occurrences, fire safety measures like alarms and escape planning, and information on fire safety education and training for students, faculty, and staff. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment requires institutions to provide information on fire safety at student fraternities and sororities, including reported incidents and efforts to improve fire safety. Each participating institution must maintain a log with current fire safety information for the campus community. Each institution must keep a log of all reported fires and false alarms, providing details such as nature, date, time, and location. This information should be accessible to the public, and periodic reports should be made to the campus community to prevent similar incidents. Additionally, institutions must submit annual statistics to the Secretary for review. Each institution participating in fire safety programs must collect and report fire statistics to the Secretary, make them public, and collaborate with fire organizations to identify effective safety practices. Fraternities and sororities recognized by the institution must also provide relevant information to the institution. The subsection outlines requirements for fraternities and sororities regarding fire safety measures for their buildings and properties. It also clarifies that the Secretary cannot mandate specific policies for fire safety at higher education institutions. The term 'campus' is defined in this subsection. The Secretary of Education is required to report to Congress. The Secretary of Education must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of this Act's enactment. The report will include an analysis of fire safety systems in college facilities, recommended fire safety standards, cost estimates for updating nonconforming buildings, and the Secretary's recommendations. The Secretary of Education will provide recommendations on meeting fire safety standards in college facilities, including funding methods, as part of a report to Congress within 2 years of this Act's enactment.
